channel.title: Minimap Walk Function
channel.description:
I am trying to make a minimap walking function.. Tried to write it all by myself.. It works.. but is not correct enough.. So i looked at some posts and i figured out that you need: - getMiniMapScale - getCompassAngle - getMapOffsetAngle
However i only used getCompassAngle..
Tried looking at RSBot but did not really made sence to me.. Can someone explain it a little bit?

Yeah your definitely dumb if you don’t cache the values.

item.title: Minimap Walk Function
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

If you look closely you’ll see most of it isn’t simular.[quote=“Taharok, post:23, topic:266051”]Sorry for posting a little late, but I thought this was appropriate.

@qauters:

    public Tile w2s(double x, double y, int height)
    {
        int screenX;
        int screenY;
        if((int)x < 128 || (int)y < 128 || (int)x > 13056 || (int)y > 13056)
        {
            screenX = -1;
            screenY = -1;
        } else
        {
            int tileCalc = tileHeight((int)x, (int)y) - height;
            x -= bot.client.getCameraX();
            y -= bot.client.getCameraY();
            tileCalc -= bot.client.getCameraZ();
            int curvex1 = CURVECOS[bot.client.getCameraCurveX()];
            int curvex2 = CURVESIN[bot.client.getCameraCurveX()];
            int curvey1 = CURVESIN[bot.client.getCameraCurveY()];
            int curvey2 = CURVECOS[bot.client.getCameraCurveY()];
            int zcalculation = (int)x * curvey2 + (int)y * curvey1 >> 16;
            y = (int)y * curvey2 - (int)x * curvey1 >> 16;
            x = zcalculation;
            zcalculation = -((int)y * curvex2) + curvex1 * tileCalc >> 16;
            y = (int)y * curvex1 + curvex2 * tileCalc >> 16;
            tileCalc = zcalculation;
            if(y < 50D)
            {
                screenY = -1;
                screenX = -1;
            } else
            {
                screenX = ((int)x << 9) / (int)y + 256;
                screenY = (tileCalc << 9) / (int)y + 167;
            }
        }
        Tile finishedTile = new Tile(screenX, screenY);
        return finishedTile;
    }

Look familiar? That is copied straight out of a decompiled Methods.class from AresBot. Why are you blaming others for copying code out of RSBot when it looks like Spel or you copied straight out of AresBot?[/quote]
In what sense is a world to screen method simulair to a world to minimap method.

our is:

        /**
         * Parameters are the local view. 128 per tile. 102x102 tiles.
         * */
        public static Point worldToScreen(double X, double Y, int height) {
                X += 5;
                Y -= 11;
                if (X < 128 || Y < 128 || X > 13056 || Y > 13056 || Bot.getClient().getGroundIntArray() == null) {
                        return new Point(-1,-1);
                }
                int tileCalculation = tileHeight((int) X, (int) Y) - height;
                X -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosX();
                tileCalculation -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosZ();
                int curvexsin = CURVESIN[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveX()];
                int curvexcos = CURVECOS[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveX()];
                Y -= Bot.getClient().getCamPosY();
                int curveysin = CURVESIN[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveY()];
                int curveycos = CURVECOS[Bot.getClient().getCameraCurveY()];
                int calculation = curvexsin * (int) Y + ((int) X * curvexcos) >> 16;
                Y = -(curvexsin * (int) X) + (int) Y * curvexcos >> 16;
                X = calculation;
                calculation = curveycos * tileCalculation - curveysin * (int) Y >> 16;
                Y = curveysin * tileCalculation + ((int) Y * curveycos) >> 16;
                tileCalculation = calculation;
                if (Y < 50) return new Point(-1,-1);
                
                int ScreenX = ((int) X << 9) / (int) Y + 256;
                int ScreenY = (tileCalculation << 9) / (int) Y + 167;

                Point p = new Point(ScreenX, ScreenY);
                if (onScreen(p)) return p;
                return new Point(-1,-1);
        }

The simulairties between those functions is as big as the simulairty between that function and the function in the client lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Minimap Walk Function

item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Similarities in structure… there is really only one way to fry an egg and i suppose you could salt it before you pepper it but it doesn’t amount to much. Also code formatting is trivial and if I want to look at someone else’s code I usually run it through the formatter before I can even look at it.

Sorry for posting a little late, but I thought this was appropriate.

@qauters:

    public Tile w2s(double x, double y, int height)
    {
        int screenX;
        int screenY;
        if((int)x < 128 || (int)y < 128 || (int)x > 13056 || (int)y > 13056)
        {
            screenX = -1;
            screenY = -1;
        } else
        {
            int tileCalc = tileHeight((int)x, (int)y) - height;
            x -= bot.client.getCameraX();
            y -= bot.client.getCameraY();
            tileCalc -= bot.client.getCameraZ();
            int curvex1 = CURVECOS[bot.client.getCameraCurveX()];
            int curvex2 = CURVESIN[bot.client.getCameraCurveX()];
            int curvey1 = CURVESIN[bot.client.getCameraCurveY()];
            int curvey2 = CURVECOS[bot.client.getCameraCurveY()];
            int zcalculation = (int)x * curvey2 + (int)y * curvey1 >> 16;
            y = (int)y * curvey2 - (int)x * curvey1 >> 16;
            x = zcalculation;
            zcalculation = -((int)y * curvex2) + curvex1 * tileCalc >> 16;
            y = (int)y * curvex1 + curvex2 * tileCalc >> 16;
            tileCalc = zcalculation;
            if(y < 50D)
            {
                screenY = -1;
                screenX = -1;
            } else
            {
                screenX = ((int)x << 9) / (int)y + 256;
                screenY = (tileCalc << 9) / (int)y + 167;
            }
        }
        Tile finishedTile = new Tile(screenX, screenY);
        return finishedTile;
    }

Look familiar? That is copied straight out of a decompiled Methods.class from AresBot. Why are you blaming others for copying code out of RSBot when it looks like Spel or you copied straight out of AresBot?
[/quote]

theres code like that almost exactly the same in the rs client[/quote]

So the naming schemes between the two bots are a coincidence? Or just the similarities in structure, etc? I am not trying to defame quaters at all here, but I don’t think he should be taking the credits he is.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:

[quote=“BAsh, post:20, topic:266051”][quote author=qauters link=topic=351272.msg2700838#msg2700838 date=1236593617]
If you look at rsbot, you see it’s initialized in the static method of the client.
This means those arrays are only calculated once. In your case it’s calculated every call.
[/quote]
LUL. missed that.
Why isnt there more flaming about C#? I mean WTF does “private static …” mean in a method?[/quote]
Hmm, I just see he said something like “but just added it here in the function so you can see it…”. Bit weird to do so anyway.
private identifier means nothing and most likely isn’t even allowed. static means the value remains the same every method call. (static local variable)

item.title: Minimap Walk Function
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Ollie:

It’s ok DarkXeD that code is straight from the client, no-one but Jagex has ownership of it.

That code was only partially found and modified/renamed. That doesn’t mean I take ownership of the code.
However hardcopieing it is something different, which you know as well.

[quote=“DarkXeD, post:16, topic:266051”][code]
private static int[] CURVESIN = new int[2048];
private static int[] CURVECOS = new int[2048];

        for (int i = 0; i < 2048; i++)
        {
                CURVESIN[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Sin(i * 0.0030679615));
                CURVECOS[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Cos(i * 0.0030679615));
        }

[/code]

i do this if the function get used… in my bot itself i do it when the class gets initialisized
but just added it here in the function so you can see it… However in quaters post it isn’t included…[/quote]
If you look at rsbot, you see it’s initialized in the static method of the client.
This means those arrays are only calculated once. In your case it’s calculated every call.

Change your class to this: (I’ll take the name Calculations as class name in this example)

class Calculations
{
   private static int[] CURVESIN = new int[2048];
   private static int[] CURVECOS = new int[2048]
   
   static Calculations
   {
      for (int i = 0; i < 2048; i++)
      {
         CURVESIN[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Sin(i * 0.0030679615));
         CURVECOS[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Cos(i * 0.0030679615));
      }
   }

   public bool WalkMiniMap(ScionTile Tile)
   {
      int mmHeight = 152;
      int mmWidth = 152;
      int mmMasterX = 516;
      int mmMasterY = 0;
      int mmGetX = 35;
      int mmGetY = 9;

      double x = Tile.getX();
      double y = Tile.getY();

      x -= GetBaseX();
      y -= GetBaseY();

      int calculatedX = ((int)(x * 4 + 2)) - GetPlayerX2() * 4;
      int calculatedY = ((int)(y * 4 + 2)) - GetPlayerY2() * 4;

      int angle = stub.botClient.GetCompassAngle() + stub.botClient.GetMapOffsetAngle() & 0x7ff;
      int actDistSq = calculatedX * calculatedX + calculatedY * calculatedY;

      int mmDist = Math.Max(mmHeight / 2, mmWidth / 2);
      if (mmDist * mmDist >= actDistSq)
      {
         int cs = CURVESIN[angle];
         int fact = 256 + stub.botClient.GetMiniMapScale();
         cs = 256 * cs / fact;
         int cc = CURVECOS[angle];
         cc = 256 * cc / fact;
         int i_25_ = -(calculatedX * cs) + calculatedY * cc >> 16;
         int i_26_ = calculatedX * cc + calculatedY * cs >> 16;

         int screenx = (mmGetX + mmMasterX) + mmWidth / 2 + i_26_;
         int screeny = -i_25_ + mmHeight / 2 + (mmGetY + mmMasterY);
         stub.mouse.ClickMouse(screenx, screeny, true);
         return true;
      }
      else
      {
         return false;//not on minimap
       }
   }
}

Read full topic

item.title: Minimap Walk Function
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:17, topic:266051”][quote author=DarkXeD link=topic=351272.msg2700383#msg2700383 date=1236553779]

	    private static int[] CURVESIN = new int[2048];
	    private static int[] CURVECOS = new int[2048];

            for (int i = 0; i < 2048; i++)
            {
                    CURVESIN[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Sin(i * 0.0030679615));
                    CURVECOS[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Cos(i * 0.0030679615));
            }

[/quote]
That code is just a small optimization. In java it took 2ms to compute the lot and that was with a VM and other crap running in the background. If you have time then add it but otherwise dont stress.[/quote]the whole point of caching the values is so you dont have to use sin()/cos() all the time, i was just stating that he would be better off actually calling the functions than calculating the whole set

Read full topic

item.title: Minimap Walk Function
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“DarkXeD, post:8, topic:266051”]Ok got the Minimap Walk done in C#
tyvm all =)

Here the code:

[CODE]
public bool WalkMiniMap(ScionTile Tile)
{

    private static int[] CURVESIN = new int[2048];
    private static int[] CURVECOS = new int[2048];

        for (int i = 0; i < 2048; i++)
        {
                CURVESIN[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Sin(i * 0.0030679615));
                CURVECOS[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Cos(i * 0.0030679615));
        }

        int mmHeight = 152;
        int mmWidth = 152;
        int mmMasterX = 516;
        int mmMasterY = 0;
        int mmGetX = 35;
        int mmGetY = 9;

        double x = Tile.getX();
        double y = Tile.getY();

        x -= GetBaseX();
        y -= GetBaseY();

        int calculatedX = ((int)(x * 4 + 2)) - GetPlayerX2() * 4;
        int calculatedY = ((int)(y * 4 + 2)) - GetPlayerY2() * 4;

        int angle = stub.botClient.GetCompassAngle() + stub.botClient.GetMapOffsetAngle() & 0x7ff;
        int actDistSq = calculatedX * calculatedX + calculatedY * calculatedY;

        int mmDist = Math.Max(mmHeight / 2, mmWidth / 2);
        if (mmDist * mmDist >= actDistSq)
        {
            int cs = CURVESIN[angle];
            int fact = 256 + stub.botClient.GetMiniMapScale();
            cs = 256 * cs / fact;
            int cc = CURVECOS[angle];
            cc = 256 * cc / fact;
            int i_25_ = -(calculatedX * cs) + calculatedY * cc >> 16;
            int i_26_ = calculatedX * cc + calculatedY * cs >> 16;

            int screenx = (mmGetX + mmMasterX) + mmWidth / 2 + i_26_;
            int screeny = -i_25_ + mmHeight / 2 + (mmGetY + mmMasterY);
            stub.mouse.ClickMouse(screenx, screeny, true);
            return true;
        }
        else
        {
            return false;//not on minimap
        }

    }

[/CODE][/quote]

DarkXeD:

Tried looking at RSBot but did not really made sence to me…

What did you think? I can’t understand it, so I copy it completely?
Except since your bot doesn’t handle interfaces correctly, it uses fixed coordinates.

What’s the point in creating your ‘own’ bot, when you hard copy most of it from RSBot.
Especially if you claim on your site: ‘The idea is to create an alternative bot to something such as RSBot.’

RSBot’s method:

	public static Point worldToMinimap(double x, double y) {
		x -= Bot.getClient().getBaseX();
		y -= Bot.getClient().getBaseY();
		int calculatedX = ((int)(x * 4 + 2)) - Bot.getClient().getMyPlayer().getX() / 32;
		int calculatedY = ((int)(y * 4 + 2)) - Bot.getClient().getMyPlayer().getY() / 32;
		
		Interface mm = Bot.getClient().getInterfaceCache()[548][64];
		 
		int angle = 0x7ff & Bot.getClient().getMinimapInt2() + Bot.getClient().getMinimapInt1();
		int actDistSq = calculatedX * calculatedX + calculatedY * calculatedY;
 
		int mmDist = Math.max(mm.getHeight() / 2, mm.getWidth() / 2);
		if (mmDist * mmDist >= actDistSq) {
			int cs = CURVESIN[angle];
			int fact = 256 + Bot.getClient().getMinimapInt3();
			cs = 256 * cs / fact;
			int cc = CURVECOS[angle];
			cc = 256 * cc / fact;
			int i_25_ = -(calculatedX * cs) + calculatedY * cc >> 16;
			int i_26_ =   calculatedX * cc  + calculatedY * cs >> 16;
 
			int screenx = (mm.getX() + mm.getMasterX()) + mm.getWidth() / 2 + i_26_;
			int screeny = -i_25_ + mm.getHeight() / 2 + (mm.getY() + mm.getMasterY());
			return new Point(screenx, screeny);
		}
		
		return new Point(-1, -1);//not on minimap
	}

item.title: Minimap Walk Function
item.dc:creator: @DarkXeD DarkXeD
item.description:
@DarkXeD wrote:

Ok got the Minimap Walk done in C#
tyvm all =)

Here the code:

        public bool WalkMiniMap(ScionTile Tile)
        {
	    //Thanks to RSBot Dev Team.
	    private static int[] CURVESIN = new int[2048];
	    private static int[] CURVECOS = new int[2048];

            for (int i = 0; i < 2048; i++)
            {
                    CURVESIN[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Sin(i * 0.0030679615));
                    CURVECOS[i] = (int)(65536.0 * Math.Cos(i * 0.0030679615));
            }

            int mmHeight = 152;
            int mmWidth = 152;
            int mmMasterX = 516;
            int mmMasterY = 0;
            int mmGetX = 35;
            int mmGetY = 9;

            double x = Tile.getX();
            double y = Tile.getY();

            x -= GetBaseX();
            y -= GetBaseY();

            int calculatedX = ((int)(x * 4 + 2)) - GetPlayerX2() * 4;
            int calculatedY = ((int)(y * 4 + 2)) - GetPlayerY2() * 4;

            int angle = stub.botClient.GetCompassAngle() + stub.botClient.GetMapOffsetAngle() & 0x7ff;
            int actDistSq = calculatedX * calculatedX + calculatedY * calculatedY;

            int mmDist = Math.Max(mmHeight / 2, mmWidth / 2);
            if (mmDist * mmDist >= actDistSq)
            {
                int cs = CURVESIN[angle];
                int fact = 256 + stub.botClient.GetMiniMapScale();
                cs = 256 * cs / fact;
                int cc = CURVECOS[angle];
                cc = 256 * cc / fact;
                int i_25_ = -(calculatedX * cs) + calculatedY * cc >> 16;
                int i_26_ = calculatedX * cc + calculatedY * cs >> 16;

                int screenx = (mmGetX + mmMasterX) + mmWidth / 2 + i_26_;
                int screeny = -i_25_ + mmHeight / 2 + (mmGetY + mmMasterY);
                stub.mouse.ClickMouse(screenx, screeny, true);
                return true;
            }
            else
            {
                return false;//not on minimap
            }

        }
